pygeoinf.gaussian_measure¶

Module for representing Gaussian measures on abstract Hilbert spaces.

class pygeoinf.gaussian_measure.GaussianMeasure(*, covariance: LinearOperator = None, covariance_factor: LinearOperator = None, expectation: T_vec = None, sample: Callable[[], T_vec] = None, inverse_covariance: LinearOperator = None, inverse_covariance_factor: LinearOperator = None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a Gaussian measure on a Hilbert space.

This class generalizes the concept of a multivariate normal distribution to abstract, potentially infinite-dimensional, Hilbert spaces. A measure is defined by its expectation (mean) and its covariance, which is a linear operator on the space.

affine_mapping(*, operator: LinearOperator = None, translation: T_vec = None) → GaussianMeasure[source]¶

Transforms the measure under the affine map y = A(x) + b.

This computes the resulting Gaussian measure for the transformed random variable y.

Parameters:

  • operator (LinearOperator, optional) – The linear operator A in the transformation. Defaults to the identity.

  • translation (vector, optional) – The translation vector b. Defaults to zero.

Returns:

The transformed measure.

Return type:

GaussianMeasure

as_multivariate_normal() → <scipy.stats._multivariate.multivariate_normal_gen object at 0x730a5cb9c610>[source]¶

Returns the measure as a scipy.stats.multivariate_normal object.

This is only possible if the measure is defined on a EuclideanSpace.

property covariance: LinearOperator¶

The covariance operator of the measure.

property covariance_factor: LinearOperator¶

The covariance factor L (s.t. C=LL*).

property covariance_factor_set: bool¶

True if a covariance factor L (s.t. C=LL*) is available.

property domain: HilbertSpace¶

The Hilbert space the measure is defined on.

property expectation: T_vec¶

The expectation (mean) of the measure.

static from_covariance_matrix(domain: HilbertSpace, covariance_matrix: np.ndarray, /, *, expectation: T_vec = None) → GaussianMeasure[source]¶

Creates a Gaussian measure from a dense covariance matrix.

The provided matrix is interpreted as the Galerkin representation of the covariance operator.

Parameters:

  • domain (HilbertSpace) – The Hilbert space for the measure.

  • covariance_matrix (np.ndarray) – The dense covariance matrix.

  • expectation (vector, optional) – The expectation of the measure. Defaults to zero.

static from_direct_sum(measures: List[GaussianMeasure]) → GaussianMeasure[source]¶

Constructs a product measure from a list of other measures.

The resulting measure is defined on the direct sum of the individual Hilbert spaces. Its covariance is a block-diagonal operator.

Parameters:

measures (list) – A list of GaussianMeasure objects.

static from_samples(domain: HilbertSpace, samples: List[T_vec]) → GaussianMeasure[source]¶

Estimates a Gaussian measure from a collection of sample vectors.

The expectation and covariance are estimated using the sample mean and sample covariance.

Parameters:

  • domain (HilbertSpace) – The space the measure is defined on.

  • samples (list) – A list of sample vectors from the domain.

static from_standard_deviation(domain: HilbertSpace, standard_deviation: float, /, *, expectation: T_vec = None) → GaussianMeasure[source]¶

Creates an isotropic Gaussian measure with scaled identity covariance.

Parameters:

  • domain (HilbertSpace) – The Hilbert space for the measure.

  • standard_deviation (float) – The standard deviation. The covariance will be sigma^2 * I.

  • expectation (vector, optional) – The expectation of the measure. Defaults to zero.

static from_standard_deviations(domain: HilbertSpace, standard_deviations: np.ndarray, /, *, expectation: T_vec = None) → GaussianMeasure[source]¶

Creates a Gaussian measure with a diagonal covariance operator.

Parameters:

  • domain (HilbertSpace) – The Hilbert space for the measure.

  • standard_deviations (np.ndarray) – A vector of standard deviations for each basis direction. The resulting covariance will be diagonal in the basis of the space.

  • expectation (vector, optional) – The expectation of the measure. Defaults to zero.

property inverse_covariance: LinearOperator¶

The inverse covariance (precision) operator.

property inverse_covariance_factor: LinearOperator¶

The inverse covariance factor.

property inverse_covariance_factor_set: bool¶

True if an inverse covariance factor is available.

property inverse_covariance_set: bool¶

True if the inverse covariance (precision) is available.

low_rank_approximation(rank: int, /, *, power: int = 0, method: str = 'fixed', rtol: float = 0.01) → GaussianMeasure[source]¶

Constructs a low-rank approximation of the measure.

The covariance operator is replaced by a low-rank approximation, which can be much more efficient for sampling and storage.

Parameters:

  • rank (int) – The target rank for the approximation.

  • power (int, optional) – Power iterations for the randomized algorithm.

  • method (str, optional) – ‘fixed’ or ‘variable’ rank method.

  • rtol (float, optional) – Relative tolerance for variable rank method.

Returns:

The new, low-rank Gaussian measure.

Return type:

GaussianMeasure

sample() → T_vec[source]¶

Returns a single random sample drawn from the measure.

sample_expectation(n: int) → T_vec[source]¶

Estimates the expectation by drawing n samples.

sample_pointwise_variance(n: int) → T_vec[source]¶

Estimates the pointwise variance by drawing n samples.

This method is only available if the domain supports vector multiplication.

property sample_set: bool¶

True if a method for drawing samples is available.

samples(n: int) → List[T_vec][source]¶

Returns a list of n random samples from the measure.

two_point_covariance(point: Any) → T_vec[source]¶

Computes the two-point covariance function.

For measures on spaces of functions, this returns the covariance between the function value at a fixed point and all other points. This requires the domain to support point evaluation (a dirac method).
